revision.text:
{{Infobox Senator |image = |caption = |term_start = January 1, 2016. |predecessor = [[Gustavo Petro]] |term_start1 = |term_end1 =January 1, 2020 |predecessor1 = |successor1 = }}The '''Superior Mayor of Bogotá''' (''Alcalde Mayor de Bogotá'') is the highest administrative and police authority of the Special District of [[Bogotá]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=327|title = Article 59, Decreto ley 1421 de 1993|date = 21 July 1993|accessdate = 7 October 2015|website = http://www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co/|publisher = Alcaldia de Bogota|last = |first = }}</ref> and the head of the executive branch of the local government of Bogotá. He heads the district's government alongside the distrital secretaries and the chiefs of the administrative departments.
The mayor is not the highest political authority of Bogota, distinction that belongs to [[Bogotá City Council|District's City Council]] which is charged with creating municipal ordinances and overseeing the mayor's duties.<ref name=":0" /> The mayor is elected every four years by [[Direct election|popular vote]] and is usually considered by general opinion to be the second most important political post in [[Colombia]] second only to the [[President of Colombia|President of the Republic]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://colombiareports.com/who-wants-to-be-mayor-of-bogota/|title = Who wants to be mayor of Bogota?|last = Dancis|first = Matthew|date = 8 May 2015|work = Colombia Reports|access-date = 7 October 2015|via = }}</ref> The Superior Mayor of Bogota's Office oversees twenty local municipalities ''(localidades)'' which each have their own local Mayors.
== Current Mayor == The current mayor is Enrique Peñalosa.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Gustavo Petro Urrego, alcalde Mayor de Bogotá {{!}} Portal Bogota {{!}} Bogota.gov.co|url = http://www.bogota.gov.co/gobierno/gustavo-petro-urrego-alcalde-mayor-de-bogota|website = www.bogota.gov.co|accessdate = 2015-10-07}}</ref>
== Functions == The Superior Mayor of Bogota is primarily tasked with executing the norms stipulated by the constitution, the law, and city ordinances approved by the City Council.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = Leyes desde 1992 - Vigencia expresa y control de constitucionalidad [DECRETO_1421_1993]|url = http://www.secretariasenado.gov.co/senado/basedoc/decreto_1421_1993.html|website = www.secretariasenado.gov.co|accessdate = 2015-10-08}}</ref>
As the highest police authority of The District he is tasked with maintaining public order, being subordinated on this matter only to the President.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = Article 186 Acuerdo 79 del Concejo de Bogotá de 2003|url = http://www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=6671|website = www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co|accessdate = 2015-10-12}}</ref> In this way the District's Mayor Office is different from other municipalities in Colombia where the Mayor's are subordinated on this matter to the governors of the respective d[[Departments of Colombia|epartments]]. The Superior Mayor of Bogota has the same police authorities as all other Colombian mayors ''and'' governors within their respective jurisdictions such as elaborating police directives, commanding all police members assigned to the district, soliciting the help of the army during an [[emergency]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Article 87. DECRETO 1355 DE 1970|url = http://www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=6945|website = www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co|accessdate = 2015-10-12}}</ref> ordering the demolition of buildings that pose a threat to public safety,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Article 216. DECRETO 1355 DE 1970.|url = http://www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=6945|website = www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co|accessdate = 2015-10-12}}</ref> regulating local commerce and the sell and distribution of liquor, amongst others.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Consulta de la Norma:|url = http://www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co/sisjur/normas/Norma1.jsp?i=9027|website = Articulo 38. Decreto Ley 1421 de 1993.|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}</ref>
As the supreme administrative authority and head of the local executive government he is charged with directing all [[public works]], as well supervising the continuous provision of all essential [[public service]]s.As the judicial representative of the city, he and his delegates are competent to carry out contracts or agreements which are legally binding for the City itself.<ref name=":3" />
The Mayor also has normative prerogatives. He might create those [[regulation]]s, resolutions or orders he considers necessary to carry out [[Local ordinance|City Ordinances]], mirroring the normative faculties the President has when it comes to implementing laws passed by [[Congress of Colombia|Congress]].<ref name=":3" />
As for his administrative duties he can freely appoint and remove the Secretaries of the various secretariats that make up the Superior Mayor's Office and the managers of the decentralized entities vinculated to his office . He may also do the same with all the functionaries of the central sector of the dependencies overseen by his office who are appointed to their post. He is tasked with overseeing the conduct of all the public servants under his authority and is competent to impose disciplinary sanctions after dues process to any of them.<ref name=":3" />
In those dependencies that belong to the Central Sector and are ascribed to his Office, he may freely create or eliminate posts, attribute said posts their functions, and decide the remuneration of those employees directly under his authority in accordance with the City's budget and in compliance with the law.<ref name=":3" />
Every year he is tasked with presenting an inform of his administration to the City Council.<ref name=":3" />
== Distrital Administration == The distrital administration of Bogota is headed by the Superior Mayor and is made up of various entities belonging to the central sector, the decentralized sector, and the local municipalities. Though the Bogotá City Council forms part of the [[Executive Branch of Colombia|executive branch of the Colombian government]], and is in charge of the administration of the city, it is not technically part of the Distrital Administration since it has no executive functions related to the administration of the city. Also the sub national oversight bodies that operate in Bogota such as the office of the Comptroller of Bogota and the ombudsman office of Bogota are not part of the Distrital Government and are completely independent from the mayor's office.
The Superior Mayor of Bogota, as the highest official within the Distrital Administration has various and ample prerogatives when it comes to the entities that make up the Central and decentralized sectors and the local municipalities. His influence is greater in those entities that make up the central sector, lesser in the decentralized entities, and limited in the local municipalities.
=== Centralized and Decentralized entities === The entities that make up the Distrital Administration are created by law or by city ordinances. It is through this entities that the Mayor can execute his functions. Centralized entities don't have legal personality and are all under the direct responsibility of the Superior Mayor's Office. Decentralized entities on the other hand are administratively autonomous and have judicial personality, nevertheless the [[managers]] in charge of the decentralized entities as well as the majority of their respective [[Board of directors|boards]] are appointed by the Mayor.<ref>{{Cite web|title = SECTOR CENTRAL Y SECTOR DESCENTRALIZADO: - Archivo Digital de Noticias de Colombia y el Mundo desde 1.990 - eltiempo.com|url = http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-517251|website = eltiempo.com|accessdate = 2015-10-08}}</ref>
==== Centralized Dependencies ==== The Centralized entities that make up the central sector are:<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = Consulta Orgánica por Entidad|url = http://www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co/sisjur/organica/tabla.html|website = www.alcaldiabogota.gov.co|accessdate = 2015-10-08}}</ref> * The General Secretariat. * The Distrital Secretariat of Governance. * The Official Firefighter's brigade. * The Distrital Secretariat of the Treasury. * The Distrital Secretariat of Planning. * The Distrital Secretariat of Economic Development. * The Distrital Secretariat of Education. * The Distrital Secretariat of Health. * The Distrital Secretariat of Social Integration. * The Distrital Secretariat of Culture, Sports and Recreation. * The Distrital Secretariat of the Environment. * The Distrital Secretariat of Mobility. * The Distrital Secretariat of Habitat. * The Distrital Secretariat of Women's issues.
==== Decentralized Entities ==== Decentralized entities, as stated above are somewhat autonomous. Nevertheless, its top officials are appointed by the Superior Mayor's Office and thus tend to follow the same political lines as the city's administration.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Article 56. Leyes desde 1992 - Vigencia expresa y control de constitucionalidad [DECRETO_1421_1993_PR001]|url = http://www.secretariasenado.gov.co/senado/basedoc/decreto_1421_1993_pr001.html|website = www.secretariasenado.gov.co|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}</ref> They have judicial personality which allows them to file lawsuits and be sued on their own responsibility.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Article 59. Leyes desde 1992 - Vigencia expresa y control de constitucionalidad [DECRETO_1421_1993_PR001]|url = http://www.secretariasenado.gov.co/senado/basedoc/decreto_1421_1993_pr001.html|website = www.secretariasenado.gov.co|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}</ref> They have an independent budget which may not be modified by the Mayor once approved by the Council.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Elementos del Derecho Administrativo General|last = Ayala|first = Caldas|publisher = Ediciones Doctrina y Ley ltda.|year = 1999|isbn = |location = Bogotá|pages = 130}}</ref> Some of this centralized entities operate as part of the [[public sector]], while others, called vinculated decentralized entities, operate as [[State-owned enterprise|private enterprises]] own or partly owned by the city's government. Each decentralized entity is ascribed(if it belongs to the public sector) or vinculated (if it operates as a private enterprise) to a centralized dependency.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://datateca.unad.edu.co/contenidos/109107/Contenido_en_linea/leccin_4_los_organismos_y_entidades_adscritas.html|title = Lección 4 Los Organismos y Entidades adscritas|date = |accessdate = 11 October 2015|website = http://datateca.unad.edu.co/|publisher = Unidad Nacional Abierta y a Distancia.|last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://datateca.unad.edu.co/contenidos/109107/Contenido_en_linea/leccin_5_las_entidades_vinculadas.html|title = Lección 5 Las Entidades vinculadas|date = |accessdate = 11 October 2015|website = http://datateca.unad.edu.co/|publisher = Universidad Nacional Abierta y a Distancia.|last = |first = }}</ref> For instance the [[Lottery of Bogota]] (a private enterprise wholly owned by the City's Government) is vinculated to the Distrital Secretariat of the Treasury.
===== Notable Examples of (Public) Decentralized Entities<ref name=":2" /> =====
* Special Registry Administrative Unit. * Prevention and Attention to Emergency Fund. * Distrital Institute of Tourism (IDT). * The 22 hospitals owned by the City. * Distrital Sports and Recreation Institute (IDRD). * Bogota Philharmonic Orchestra. * Botanical Garden Jose Celestino Mutis. * Urban Development Institute (IDU).
===== Notable Examples of Vinculated Decentralized Entities ===== * Lottery of Bogota. * Francisco Jose de Caldas Distrital University. * Capital Salud E.P.S. S.A.S (healthcare provider). * [[Canal Capital]] (Television Channel). * [[TransMilenio|Transmilenio S.A]]. * [[ETB (company)|Empresa de Telecomunicaciones de Bogotá ETB]] (Telephony provider). * Empresa de Energía de Bogotá EBB (electricity utility company). * Empresa de Acueducto y Alcantarillado EAAB (water works utility company).
=== Local Mayors === Local mayors are elected by the Local Administrative Councils out of a three candidate shortlist elaborated by the Superior Mayor.
== See also == * [[List of mayors of Bogotá|Lists of Mayors of Bogota]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Politicians from Bogotá]] [[Category:Cundinamarca Department]] [[Category:Bogotá]] [[Category:Executive branch of Colombia]] [[Category:Colombia-related lists]]

{{multiple issues| {{original research|date=May 2018}} {{refimprove|date=May 2018}} }} {{Infobox country telephone plan | country = India | country_link = India | continent = Asia | map_image = India (no claimed territories).svg | map_caption = Location of India | map_size = 220px | map_alt = | regulator = [[Department of Telecommunications]] | plan_membership = | plan_type = Closed | nsn_length = 10 | number_format = | plan_link = {{URL | http://www.dot.gov.in/national-numbering-plan-list | National Numbering Plan - 2003}} | plan_date = 13 April 2015 | country_calling_code = +91 | international_prefix = 00 | trunk_prefix = 0 | codes_list = }}
[[File:STD ISD PCO Indian telephone.jpg|thumb|A [[public call office]] (PCO) in [[Auroville]], [[India]]]]
Telephone numbers in India are administered under the ''National Numbering Plan of 2003'' by the [[Department of Telecommunications]]. The numbering plan was last updated in 2015. The [[International Telecommunication Union]] has assigned the country calling code "91" to India.
==Fixed line (landline) numbers== [[Subscriber Trunk Dialling]] (STD) codes are assigned to each city/town/village, with the larger Metro cities having shorter area codes (STD codes), which are from 2 to 8 digits long. For example, *'''11''' - [[New Delhi]], [[Delhi]] *'''22''' - [[Mumbai]], [[Maharashtra]] *'''33''' - [[Kolkata]], [[West Bengal]] *'''44''' - [[Chennai]], [[Tamil Nadu]] *'''20''' - [[Pune]], [[Maharashtra]] *'''40''' - [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]], [[Telangana]] *'''79''' - [[Ahmedabad]], [[Gujarat]] *'''80''' - [[Bangalore]], [[Karnataka]]
Tier-2 Cities in India have STD code with 3 digits. For example,
*'''120''' - [[Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh|Ghaziabad]]/[[Noida]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] *'''124''' - [[Gurgaon]], [[Haryana]] *'''129''' - [[Faridabad]], [[Haryana]] *'''135''' - [[Dehradun]], [[Uttarakhand]] *'''141''' - [[Jaipur]], [[Rajasthan]] *'''161''' - [[Ludhiana]], [[Punjab]] *'''172''' - [[Chandigarh]], [[Punjab]] *'''172''' - [[Mohali]], [[Punjab]] *'''172''' - [[Panchkula]], [[Haryana]] *'''175''' - [[Patiala]], [[Punjab]] *'''181''' - [[Jalandhar]], [[Punjab]] *'''231''' - [[Kolhapur]], [[Maharashtra]] *'''240''' - [[Aurangabad, Maharashtra]] *'''260''' - [[Valsad district|Valsad, Gujarat]] & [[Daman, India]] *'''261''' - [[Surat]], [[Gujarat]] *'''343''' - [[Durgapur]], [[West Bengal]] *'''484''' - [[Kochi]], [[Kerala]] *'''512''' - [[Kanpur]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] *'''522''' - [[Lucknow]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] *'''532''' - [[Allahabad]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] *'''542''' - [[Varanasi]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] *'''551''' - [[Gorakhpur]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] *'''562''' - [[Agra]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] *'''581''' - [[Bareilly]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] *'''591''' - [[Moradabad]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] *'''621''' - [[Muzaffarpur]], [[Bihar]] *'''612''' - [[Patna]], [[Bihar]] *'''641''' - [[Bhagalpur]], [[Bihar]] *'''657''' - [[Jamshedpur]], [[Jharkhand]] *'''870''' - [[Warangal]], [[Telangana]] *'''891''' - [[Visakhapatnam]], [[Andhra Pradesh]]
Kanpur and Lucknow were the two cities between which the first STD call of the country was made.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}}
The total length of all phone numbers (STD code and the phone number) in [[India]] is constant at 10 digits, for example 7513200000 signifies a STD code i.e. 751 [[Gwalior]] & the phone number 3200000.
Land line numbers are at most 8 digits long (usually in major metros).
=== Landline operators === Due to the availability of multiple operators offering fixed line services (either over wire or wireless), there is an operator-code for each telephone number, which is the first digit in the phone number. These are:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.trai.gov.in/sites/default/files/spaper13mar09.pdf|title=National Numbering Plan – a revised approach suggested by TRAI for achieving greater transparency and efficiency|date=March 2009|website=trai.gov.in|publisher=Telecom Regulatory Authority of India|pages=9-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170703073108/http://trai.gov.in/sites/default/files/spaper13mar09.pdf|archive-date=2017-07-03|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiacallinginfo.com/india-local-subscriber-numbers#india-landline-phone-numbers|title=Local Phone Number Formats in India|last=|first=|date=|website=IndiaCallingInfo.com|publisher=CallingGuides.com|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref>
* [[BSNL]] / [[MTNL]] - Numbers start with a '2' * [[Reliance Communications]] - Numbers start with a '3' * [[Bharti Airtel]] - Numbers start with a '4' * [[MTS India]] / HFCL - Numbers start with a '5' * [[Tata Indicom]] - Numbers start with a '6' * Datacom Solutions - Numbers start with a '7'
Thus, a number formatted as '''020-30303030''' means a fixed-line Reliance number in Pune, while '''011-20000198''' is an MTNL fixed line in Delhi and '''033-45229320''' is a fixed-line Airtel number in Kolkata, and '''07582-221434''' is a BSNL number from [[Sagar, Madhya Pradesh|Sagar]], Madhya Pradesh.
=== Format for dialing landline numbers === No prefix is required to call from one landline to another in the same STD area. A prefix of "0+STD code" is required to dial from a landline phone in one STD code area to another. A prefix of "0+STD code" is required to dial from a mobile phone in India to any landline number, irrespective of STD area.
For example, to dial a landline number in Indore, one would have to dial * from a landline in Indore: the phone number * from a landline in Mumbai: 0731 and then the phone number * from any mobile phone in India: 0731 and then the phone number * from outside India: Country Code 91 then 731 and then the phone number
Before 10 March 2009, as per [[Department of Telecommunications (India)|Department of Telecommunications]] [[memorandum]] dated 9 February 2009.<ref name="dotmemo95">{{cite web|url=http://www.dot.gov.in/as/2009/numbering%20plan_25.02.2009.pdf|title=DoT Memorandum 10th Feb 09.|accessdate=2009-04-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101027155604/http://dot.gov.in/as/2009/numbering%20plan_25.02.2009.pdf|archivedate=2010-10-27|df=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/TRAI-for-10-digit-landline-numbers-to-meet-crunch/article16138959.ece TRAI for 10-digit landline numbers to meet crunch]</ref> there were some exceptions to this general rule for STD areas falling close to each other (within a radius of 200 kilometre), where "0" can be replaced with "95" e.g. to dial Delhi from [[Gurgaon]], one dials 9511+landline number.
== Mobile numbers == {{Main article|Mobile telephone numbering in India}}
A typical mobile number in India is "+91-XXXX-NNNNNN". Where the first four digits indicate a operator's code, while the remaining six digits are unique to the subscribers. However, with portability in place, the first four digits may not indicate a particular operator.
==Short code== There are many companies in the Indian market who rent keywords, on a monthly basis, whose characters, on a typical mobile phone keypad, represent short codes. Short codes are five digits in length and have to start with the digit '5' like 58888 as of 2007. Previously, they were four-digit in number and could be of any combination, like 8888 or 7827. The current five digits can be extended by three digits further representing 3 additional characters. Messages sent to these Short Codes are commonly referred to as Premium Rate SMS Messages and cost from per message depending on the operator as well as the service and the company.
==Telemarketing== Telemarketers have been issued 10-digit telephone numbers starting with 140 (140XXXXXXX) by the [[Department of Telecommunications]] on [[TRAI]]'s request.<ref>[http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/pesky-calls-trai-fails-to-set-deadline/1/136227.html Trai fails to set deadline on pesky calls]</ref><ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-09-27/goa/42458841_1_telecom-service-providers-trai-telecom-regulatory-authority 'Publishing tariff plans by telecom service providers mandatory']</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.dot.gov.in/ Department of Telecommunications, Government of India] * [http://www.trai.gov.in/ Telecom Regulatory Authority of India] * [http://www.dot.gov.in/sites/default/files/nnp2003.pdf India National Numbering Plan of 2003] {{Telephone numbers in Asia}} {{Telecommunications}}
[[Category:Telephone numbers by country|India]] [[Category:Telephone numbers in India| ]] [[Category:India communications-related lists]]

{{citation style|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox lake | name = Veliki Galijaš | image =Veliki Galijas.jpg | caption =Veliki Galijaš panorama | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = | coords = {{coord|44.832|20.437|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = [[Danube]], [[Sava]] | outflow = [[Danube]] | catchment = | basin_countries = [[Serbia]] | length = {{convert|1,300|m|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|25|m|abbr=on}} | area = {{convert|24|ha|abbr=on}} | depth = | max-depth = | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = | cities = [[Belgrade]] }}
'''Veliki Galijaš''' or just '''Galijaš''' ([[Serbian language|Serbian]] [[Cyrillic]]: '''Велики Галијаш''') is a canal turned lake on the [[Great War Island]], within the city of [[Belgrade]], the capital of [[Serbia]].
The former canal is one of the major physical features on the island. In time, the canal was cut off from the [[Danube]] and effectivelly turned into a lake, with an area of 0.24 km² and became the major natural bird and fish spawning area on the island, with 196 bird and 90 fish species living in it. However, during the [[drought]]y years the lake drained out completely causing damage to the closed [[eco-system]] centred on it. In August 2007 the digging began of a 300 m-long canal which would reconnect Veliki Galijaš with the Danube and prevent the seasonal drying of the lake. After it was completed, fish from the Sava began swimming into the Veliki Galijaš. Fishing in the lake is forbidden as in the river zone up to 50m from the island's coastline.
Celebrating June 29, the international Day of the Danube, an eco-camp made of [[pile dwelling]]s for the students of the [[Belgrade University]] was opened near the lake in 2007. A 15 m-high lookout is to be erected west of Veliki Galijaš so as the entire network of visitor centres on the unsinkable points around the lake and throughout the island for the studying of the bird life. Bio-laboratory is also scheduled for construction.
== See also == * [[List of lakes in Serbia]]
== References == {{reflist}} * [[Politika]] daily (2007 editions: February 1, p. 24; July 13, p. 25; July 14, p. 24; August 17, p. 23; 2008 editions: February 5; March 20, p. 25)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Veliki Galijas}} [[Category:Geography of Belgrade]] [[Category:Lakes of Serbia]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=April 2013}} [[File:Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign Logo.jpg|thumb|Official logo of the Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign]]
The '''Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign''' is a non-racial<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/201103171045.html Manyi and Manuel - Why Apartheid Didn't Die], Leonard Gentle, ''All Africa'', March 2011</ref> popular movement<ref>[http://www.leadershiponline.co.za/articles/politics/1161-sas-angry-poor The flames of Phaphamani], Pedro Tabensky, ''Leadership Magazine'', 7 March 2011</ref> made up of poor and oppressed communities in [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]].<ref>[http://www.waronwant.org/overseas-work/informal-economy/anti-eviction-in-south-africa Anti-eviction in South Africa], ''WarOnWant''</ref><ref name="thenation1">[http://www.thenation.com/article/fighting-foreclosure-south-africa Fighting Foreclosure in South Africa ], by the Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign, ''The Nation Magazine''</ref> It was formed in November 2000<ref>[http://abahlali.org/files/Oldfield%20&%20Stokke%20WCAEC%20Research%20Report.pdf Building unity in diversity: Social movement activism in the Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign], Sophie Oldfield & Kristian Stokke, 2004, p.13</ref> with the aim of fighting [[eviction]]s, water cut-offs and poor health services, obtaining free electricity, securing decent housing, and opposing [[police brutality]].<ref>[http://antieviction.org.za/2010/12/06/re-launch-of-the-western-cape-aec-focuses-on-a-renewed-coordinated-fight-against-evictions-water-cutoffs-electricity-cutoffs-and-for-decent-housing-for-all/ Re-launch of the Western Cape AEC focuses on a renewed coordinated fight against evictions, water cutoffs, electricity cutoffs and for decent housing for all!], Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign, 6 December 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.capetownmagazine.com/whats-the-deal-with/Whats-the-Deal-With-Toyitoyi/125_22_17384 What's the Deal With the Toyi-Toyi?], Lisa Nevitt, ''Cape Town Magazine'', September 2010</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2010-12-23-on-the-other-side-of-mountain On the Other Side of the Mountain], Niren Tolsi, ''Mail & Guardian'', 23 December 2010</ref><ref>[http://antieviction.org.za/related-writing-and-resources/housing-battles-in-post-apartheid-south-africa-the-case-of-mandela-park-khayelitsha/ Housing battles in post-Apartheid South Africa: The Case of Mandela Park, Khayelitsha] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524193411/http://antieviction.org.za/related-writing-and-resources/housing-battles-in-post-apartheid-south-africa-the-case-of-mandela-park-khayelitsha/ |date=24 May 2012 }}, by [[Martin Legassick]], ''South African Labour Bulletin'', 2003</ref>
The movement is the oldest of the first generation of so-called '[[new social movements]]' to spring up after the end of [[apartheid]] and is known for its [[direct action]] style militancy, its refusal of all forms of [[vanguardism]], including NGO ([[Non-governmental organization|Non-Governmental Organisations]]) [[authoritarianism]].<ref name="thenation1"/><ref>[http://www.indymedia.org/el/2007/12/897831.shtml South African Grassroots Movements Rebel Against NGO Authoritarianism], Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign, ''Indymedia'', 9 December 2007</ref><ref>[http://abahlali.org/node/585 Rethinking Public Participation from Below ], by Richard Pithouse, ''Critical Dialogue'', 2006</ref><ref name="ceasefiremagazine1">[http://ceasefiremagazine.co.uk/columns/the-anti-imperialist/the-anti-imperialist-south-africa-a-revolution-in-progress/ South Africa: A Revolution in Progress], ''Ceasefire'', 9 January 2009</ref> The movement has sought to retain its autonomy from NGOs<ref>[http://abahlali.org/files/Oldfield%20&%20Stokke%20WCAEC%20Research%20Report.pdf Building unity in diversity: Social movement activism in the Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign], Sophie Oldfield & Kristian Stokke, 2004</ref> and publicly refused to work with some local NGOs<ref>[http://www.indymedia.org/el/2007/12/897831.shtml South African Grassroots Movements Rebel Against NGO Authoritarianism]</ref> and insists that the middle class left respect the autonomy of grassroots movements.
The AEC is a founding member of the [[Poor People's Alliance]] and, along with the other members of the alliance, refuses all electoral politics and encourages the development of popular power rather than voting for political parties.<ref name="ceasefiremagazine1"/><ref>[http://www.capetimes.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=4780755 See the article 'Anti Eviction Campaign urges poor to boycott elections' by Aziz Hartley, ''Cape Times'', 5 January 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.ekklesia.co.uk/node/9282] Grassroots movements plan to boycott South African poll ''Ekklesia'', 29 April 2009</ref><ref>[http://dailymaverick.co.za/article/2012-07-02-analysis-the-das-battle-to-buddy-up-to-the-everyman The DA's battle to buddy up to the everyman], Osiame Molefe, ''The Daily Maverick'', 2 July 2012 </ref>
The AEC mobilised against the 2008 xenophobic attacks in the areas where it was strong.<ref>[http://www.vocfm.co.za/index.php?section=news&category=vocnews&article=48045 Deal aims to stop xenophobia], ''VOCFM'', 19 August 2009</ref><ref>[http://antieviction.org.za/2009/08/24/aec-and-stakeholders-in-recent-anti-xenophobia-negotiations-head-to-parliament-today/ AEC and stakeholders in recent anti-xenophobia negotiations head to parliament today], ''Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign'', 24 August 2009</ref><ref>[http://mg.co.za/article/2009-06-19-xenophobia-still-smoulders-in-cape-townships Xenophobia still smoulders in Cape townships], Mandisi Majavu, ''Mail & Guardian'', 19 June, 2009</ref>
The AEC opposed evictions related to the [[FIFA 2010 World Cup]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/africa/10205455.stm South Africans fight eviction for World Cup car park], Mohammed Allie ''BBC News'' 2 June 2010</ref>
==Communities== The AEC is currently an umbrella body for over 10 community organisations,<ref name="antieviction.org.za">[http://antieviction.org.za/about-us/ About Us: Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign]</ref> crisis committees, and concerned residents movements who have come together to organise and demand their rights to basic services.<ref name="waronwant">[http://www.waronwant.org/overseas-work/informal-economy/anti-eviction-in-south-africa Anti-eviction in South Africa]</ref> The organisations that make up the AEC include but are not limited to:
* Tafelsig [[Mitchell's Plain]] * [[Blikkiesdorp]] Informal Committee ([[Delft,_Cape_Town|Delft]])<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/201110281069.html Cape Town Administration Violates the Rights of the Poor], Carmen Ludwig, All Africa, 27 October 2011</ref> * The Crossroads Anti-Eviction Campaign ([[Nyanga, Cape Town|Nyanga]]) * The Delft Integrated Network ([[Delft,_Cape_Town|Delft]]) * The Eastridge Anti-Eviction Campaign ([[Mitchell's Plain]]) * The Gugulethu Anti-Eviction Campaign ([[Gugulethu]]) * The Hanover Park Anti-Eviction Campaign ([[Hanover Park, Cape Town|Hanover Park]]) * The [[Mandela Park Backyarders]] ([[Khayelitsha]]) * Newfields Village Community Representative Committee ([[Hanover Park, Cape Town|Hanover Park]]) * Nyanga East Anti-Eviction Campaign ([[Nyanga, Cape Town|Nyanga]]) * [[The Symphony Way Anti-Eviction Campaign]] ([[Delft,_Cape_Town|Delft]]) * The Woodridge Anti-Eviction Campaign ([[Mitchell's Plain]]) * Zille-Raine Heights (Parkwood)<ref name="antieviction.org.za"/>
Affiliated movements and committees in the Western Cape: * [[QQ Section]] Concerned Residents ([[Khayelitsha]]) * [[Abahlali baseMjondolo]] of the Western Cape * [[Sikhula Sonke]] Women Farmworkers Union * [[Joe Slovo Liberative Residents]] ([[Langa, Cape Town|Langa]]) * Hangberg Solution Seekers Association ([[Hout Bay]]) * KTC Concerned Residents Movement ([[Nyanga, Cape Town|Nyanga]]) * Mitchell’s Plain Concerned Hawkers and Traders Association ([[Mitchell's Plain]]) * Gugulethu Informal Traders ([[Gugulethu]]) * Gatesville Informal Traders Association (Athlone)<ref name="antieviction.org.za"/>
==Coordinators==
The Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign is an umbrella structure with an executive committee of a chairperson, a vice chairperson, a secretary, a vice secretary, a treasurer, and five regional coordinators. <ref>[http://antieviction.org.za/2010/12/06/re-launch-of-the-western-cape-aec-focuses-on-a-renewed-coordinated-fight-against-evictions-water-cutoffs-electricity-cutoffs-and-for-decent-housing-for-all/ Re-launch of the Western Cape AEC focuses on a renewed coordinated fight against evictions, water cutoffs, electricity cutoffs and for decent housing for all!], ''Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign'', 6 December 2010</ref> <ref>[http://antieviction.org.za/western-cape-anti-eviction-campaign-detailed-contact-list/ Contact List], ''Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign''</ref>
==Activities== The AEC opposes evictions and water and electricity cut-offs on many different levels.<ref name="thenation1"/> Activities range from legal actions that challenge the constitutionality of evictions, to mass mobilisation and popular education initiatives, to organisation and capacity building programs.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="ceasefiremagazine1"/> The movement has also confronted local gangs and in July 2012 one of its leading activists, Soraya Nordien, was murdered following threats from gang members.<ref>[http://www.sacsis.org.za/site/article/1362 Helen Zille's Hopeless Handling of Cape Gang Violence], Anna Majavu, ''SACSIS'', 13 July 2012</ref>
==Campaigns== Since its inception, the Anti-Eviction Campaign (AEC) has called for an end to all evictions and cut-offs of basic services in the Western Cape.<ref name="thenation1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.landaction.org/display.php?article=67|title=Stop Forced Removals & Evictions! Stop Privatisation!|publisher=Land Research Action Network}}</ref> In 2001, the AEC achieved a 6-month moratorium on all evictions in the Cape Town Unicity.<ref>[http://jas.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/41/1-2/95 Subjectivity, Politics and Neoliberalism in Post-apartheid Cape Town]</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenation.com/doc/20090420/western_cape|title=Fighting Foreclosure in South Africa |publisher=The Nation Magazine}}</ref> Even though the DA had declared the moratorium, illegal evictions continued.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.queensu.ca/msp/pages/In_The_News/2001/June/wc.htm|title=WESTERN CAPE ANTI-EVICTION COMMITTEE PRESS STATEMENT}}</ref>
The movement strongly supported the struggle for the [[Symphony Way Pavement Dwellers]] to resist forced removal to the notorious [[Blikkiesdorp]] transit camp and to demand access to decent housing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://antieviction.org.za/2008/04/14/delft-symphony-pavement-dwellers-building-a-new-world-one-child-at-a-time/|title=Delft-Symphony Pavement Dwellers building a new world – one child at a time}}</ref>
[[No Land! No House! No Vote!]] is the name of a campaign by autonomous grassroots movements to boycott elections and reject party politics and [[vote banking]] in South Africa. In 2009, the [[Poor People's Alliance]] voted to boycott the national elections under the No Land! No House! No Vote! Banner.<ref name="thenation1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abahlali.org/node/865|title="No Vote" Campaigns are not a Rejection of Democracy|publisher=Mail and Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.capetimes.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=4780755|title=Anti Eviction Campaign urges poor to boycott elections |publisher=Cape Times}}</ref>
The 2010 FIFA World Cup was connected to a large number of evictions in South Africa which many claimed were meant to 'beautify the city'.<ref name="o.seattletimes.nwsource.com">[http://o.seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/worldcup/2012084369_soccersaf11.html South Africa's poor complain of evictions as country prepares to host World Cup], Sudarsan Raghavan, [[The Washington Post]], 20 June 2010</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://baystatebanner.com/world19-2008-07-10|title=In South Africa, evicted residents struggle|publisher=Bay State Banner|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913072934/http://www.baystatebanner.com/world19-2008-07-10|archivedate=13 September 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>[http://mondediplo.com/2008/05/13southafrica Le Monde Diplomatique]</ref> The WC-AEC campaigned against all evictions caused by the event. The campaign's hotspots included the anti-gentrification issues in Gympie Street and other parts of Woodstock,<ref>{{cite news|url= http://bushradionews.blogspot.com/2006/04/gympie-street-evictions.html|title=Gympie Street evictions |publisher=BushRadio}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://antieviction.org.za/2009/05/22/this-is-not-a-game/|title=This is not a game!}}</ref> the national [[N2 Gateway]] housing project and its evictions in [[Joe Slovo Informal Settlement|Joe Slovo]] and [[Delft]],<ref>{{cite news|url= http://antieviction.org.za/2008/08/17/call-to-demonstrate-at-constitutional-court-21-august-against-joe-slovo-eviction/|title=Call to demonstrate at constitutional court|publisher=Joe Slovo Task Team}}</ref> Sea Point evictions, and evictions in Q-Town next to Athlone Stadium.
The movement is committed to opposing xenophobia and has been particularly active in this regard in [[Gugulethu]]<ref>[http://www.ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=47285 'Xenophobia Still Smouldering' by Mandisi Majavu, IPS, 19 June 2009]</ref> where it has set up a forum<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=3069&art_id=vn20090707052329645C240973 Gugulethu, traders to hold follow-up meeting], Cape Times, 7 July 2009</ref> for these issues to be discussed. According to both the media<ref>[http://www.sowetan.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=1012767 'Xenophobic tensions in Gugulethu calm down', Anna Majavu, The Sowetan, 5 June 2009]</ref> and the local police<ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=13&art_id=nw20090615195308848C865193 Independent Online, 'You could see the anger in their eyes', Caryn Dolley, 15 June 2009]</ref> the forum has had considerable success in reducing xenophobic hostility. However the movement's anti-xenophobic work has cost it some popular support and resulted in an arson attack on one of the movement's leaders.<ref>[http://sds.ukzn.ac.za/default.php?2,6,684,4,0 Chance, K. (2010) The Work of violence:a timeline of armed attacks at Kennedy Road]. School of Development Studies Research Report, 83, July 2010.</ref>
The movement produces its own media.<ref>Social Movement Media in Post-Apartheid South Africa, by Wendy Willems,''Encyclopaedia of Social Movement Media'' (Ed. John D. H. Downing, Southern Illinois University, Carbondale, 2011)</ref>
==Poor People's Alliance== In September 2008 the Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign, together with [[Abahlali baseMjondolo]], the [[Landless People's Movement]] and the Rural Network (Abahlali baseplasini) formed the [[Poor People's Alliance]].<ref>[http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2009/01/12/18562116.php The Struggle for Land & Housing in Post-Apartheid South Africa by Toussaint Losier, Left Turn, January 2009]</ref><ref>[http://www.zcommunications.org/znet/viewArticle/21529 'Participatory Society: Urban Space & Freedom', by Chris Spannos, Z-Net, 29 May 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090606072510/http://www.zcommunications.org/znet/viewArticle/21529 |date=6 June 2009 }}</ref> The poor people's alliance refuses electoral politics under the banner '[[No Land! No House! No Vote!]]'.<ref name="ceasefiremagazine1"/><ref>The alliance, and its position on electoral politics, is mentioned in the speech by S'bu Zikode at http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/2008/12/415682.html</ref> It has been reported that "Nearly 75% of South Africans aged 20-29 did not vote in the 2011 [local government] elections" and that "South Africans in that age group were more likely to have taken part in (sic) violent street protests against the local ANC than to have voted for the ruling party".<ref>[http://mg.co.za/article/2013-01-29-deep-read-anc-risks-losing-born-free-voters Deep Read: 'Born free' voters may not choose ANC], JON HERSKOVITZ, ''Mail & Guardian'', 29 January 2013</ref>
==Influence==
[[Take Back the Land]]<ref>[http://www.takebacktheland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=99:take-back-the-land-in-south-africa&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=60 Take Back the Land in South Africa]</ref> in [[Miami]] and the Chicago Anti-Eviction Campaign<ref>[http://chicagoantieviction.org/ Chicago Anti-Eviction Campaign]</ref><ref>[http://www.mg.co.za/article/2010-12-23-fear-and-loathing-in-obamaland Fear and loathing in Obamaland], Niren Tolsi,''Mail & Guardian'', 23 December 2010</ref><ref>[http://chicagoantieviction.org/2012/02/february-rent-party-fundraiser-for.html February "Rent Party" Fundraiser for Freedom], ''Chicago Anti-Eviction Campaign''</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/02/magazine/how-chicagos-housing-crisis-ignited-a-new-form-of-activism.html?_r=2&pagewanted=all& The Death and Life of Chicago] By BEN AUSTEN, ''New York Times'', 29 May 2013</ref> have both stated that their work is inspired by that of the Western Cape Anti-Eviction Campaign. The Chicago Anti-Eviction Campaign has used the slogan 'No House No Vote'.<ref>[http://inthesetimes.com/uprising/entry/13663/whos_house_our_house_chicago_communities_hold_meeting_to_demand_eviction_mo/ Chicago Communities Demand Eviction Moratorium], by MILES KAMPF-LASSIN, ''In these Times'', 10 August 2012</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Yngvar Nielsen | image = 20255 Yngvar Nielsen.jpg | alt = Yngvar Nielsen in 1898 | caption = Yngvar Nielsen in 1898 | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1843|07|29}} | birth_place = [[Arendal]], [[Aust-Agder]] | death_date = {{death date and age |1916|03|02 |1843|07|29 |df=yes}} | death_place = | nationality = [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]] | other_names = | occupation = [[Historian]], [[politician]], [[geographer]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Yngvar Nielsen''' (29 July 1843, [[Arendal]], [[Aust-Agder]] – 2 March 1916) was a [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]] [[historian]], [[politician]], [[geographer]] and pioneer of [[tourism]] in Norway.
==Background== Nielsen was born in [[Arendal]], [[Aust-Agder]]. He was the son of Norwegian Telegraph Director, [[Carsten Tank Nielsen]] (1818–92) and Alvilde Olsen (1821–1890). Nielsen descended on both father's and mother's side from the established civil and commercial bourgeoisie.<ref name=nbl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=|title=Yngvar Nielsen |encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Åsmund |last=Svendsen |editor=[[Knut Helle|Helle, Knut]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget |location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Yngvar_Nielsen/utdypning |language=Norwegian |accessdate=23 May 2010}}</ref> His grandfather, [[Jacob Nielsen (born 1768)|Jacob Nielsen]],<ref name=nbl-jacobnielsen>{{cite encyclopedia|year=|title=Jacob Nielsen |encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Odd Arvid |last=Storsveen |editor=[[Knut Helle|Helle, Knut]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget |location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Jacob_Nielsen/utdypning |language=Norwegian |accessdate=23 May 2010}}</ref> had been one of Christiania's largest lumber dealers and director of the National Bank.<ref name=nbl/><ref name=nbl-tanknielsen>{{cite encyclopedia|year=|title=Carsten Tank Nielsen |encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Harald |last=Rinde |editor=[[Knut Helle|Helle, Knut]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget |location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Carsten_Tank_Nielsen/utdypning |language=Norwegian |accessdate=23 May 2010}}</ref>
==Career== Nielsen studied philology and took a linguistic-historical degree in 1865. After three years as a teacher at Nissens Latin School (interrupted by several rounds of archival studies in [[Sweden]] and [[Denmark]]), he was employed in the [[National Archival Services of Norway]] (''Arkivverket'') from 1869 to 1978 and at the same time served as librarian at the [[Deichman Library]]. He was appointed manager of the University's Ethnographic Museum in 1877, and the following year he became research fellow in history and geography. In 1880, he completed his philosophical doctorate thesis on the council [[Riksrådet]].<ref name=nbl/>
Nielsen was an important advisor in Norway to King [[Oscar II of Sweden and Norway]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} He had close connections to the [[Swedish Royal Family|Royal Family]], and was the tutor of the Swedish princes [[Oscar, Prince Bernadotte|Oscar]] and [[Prince Eugen, Duke of Närke|Eugen]] during their stay at the [[University of Christiania]] in the 1880s.<ref name=nbl/>
Nielsen was chairman of the [[Norwegian Historical Association]], and edited the journal ''[[Historisk Tidsskrift (Norway)|Historisk Tidsskrift]]'' from 1903 to 1912.<ref name=nbl/> Together with [[Ludvig Ludvigsen Daae]] he co-edited the journal ''Vidar'' 1887–89. Nielsen was a board member of the [[Norwegian Trekking Association]] from 1879 and Chairman 1890–1908. In 1879 he released the travel guide ''[[Reisehaandbog over Norge]]'', popularly called ''Yngvar'', which appeared in 12 editions until 1915 and came to play an important role in the spread of tourism.<ref name=nbl/> His [[guide book]]s were published in [[English language|English]] and [[German language|German]].<ref name=nbl/>
Probably Nielsen's most important work as an historian was ''Lensgreve Johan Caspar Herman Wedel Jarlsberg'' (three volumes, 1901–1902), his biography of [[Johan Caspar Herman Wedel-Jarlsberg]] (1779–1840). Wedel-Jarlsberg played an active role in the [[Norwegian Constituent Assembly]] at [[Eidsvoll]] in 1814 and was the first native Norwegian to hold the post of [[Governor of Norway]] during the union with Sweden.
==Personal life== In October 1870, he married Karen Anne Juliane Hedvig [[Wedel-Jarlsberg]] (1847–1927), the daughter of Peder Anker Count Wedel-Jarlsberg (1909–1893). Nielsen was a member of the [[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]] from 1875 and the [[Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters]] from 1897. He received Reward Medal from King Oscar II in 1882, was appointed Knight of the [[Order of St. Olav]] in 1894 and received the Commander Cross 1911. He was appointed Knight of the [[Order of the Polar Star|Nordstjärneorden]] and appointed to several other foreign orders.<ref name=nbl/>
==Selected works== *''En Christianiensers Erindringer'' (1910) *''Under Oscar IIs Regjering'' (1912) *''Fra Johan Sverdrups Dage'' (1913) *''Da Unionen skulde briste'' (1915)
